When did the prefix ‘Anti’ change it's meaning? Apparently, it no longer means against something it means ‘I agree but only in a very small number of circumstances’
@OYFallTSM @DanH_9 You've not really put forward much if an argument in fact your recent tweet would suggest we think the same
@DanH_9 @OYFallTSM If everyone already knows anti-exclusion means would rather not too then why the need for this statement? https://t.co/HOUdALsWFu
@OYFallTSM @DanH_9 Not sure where the need for insults has come from but really showing you don't have much of an argument.
@OYFallTSM @DanH_9 I've not denied that ‘pro’ means ‘for’ and ‘anti’ means ‘against’ - that's literally what I've been saying for the whole time

@OYFallTSM @DanH_9 As a science teacher then use of language is very important especially as large number if scientific words cow from Greek and Latin roots. Understand the root and you will understand what a wod means before you even study it in depth.

@DanH_9 @OYFallTSM If you asked are you anti-exclusion or pro-exclusion then they would say Pro. 

Not sure any school would publically describe itself in any term around exclusion unless it was making a politically motivated we never exclude stand point.

@DanH_9 @OYFallTSM No one wants to exclude unless they have to - I've never meet anyone who would. But they aren't anti-exclusion (and I dont know personally anyone who would call themselves that either) because they are not against the use of exclusion. The are for the use of exclusion

@DanH_9 @OYFallTSM No, because ‘pro’ literally means for something. If you will use it too then you are for it all be it in limited circumstances. 

I've asked this before but you didn't answer - In your idea world do you never want a child excluded from school?
@OYFallTSM @DanH_9 No I just have an issue with people changing the meaning of words that already have a well known meaning seemingly to push their own narrative

@OYFallTSM @DanH_9 I'm not so sure about that - you didn't seem to have a response to when I highlighted the actual meaning of both the prefixes or how you can say you are against something but support it in certain circumstances.

@PastoralPolly @Mr_Keyte If you post something of your own online then you should expect people to give their opinions. Especially in education which seems to be the most opinionated profession in the world
@Mr_Keyte Way too much going on in that room. The cognitive overload is going to be through the roof
@OYFallTSM @DanH_9 It would appear you're not sure either
@DanH_9 @OYFallTSM Now I'm really confused now. In your idea world do you never want a child excluded from school?

@DanH_9 @OYFallTSM If you think there are times when a child should be excluded from school you can't claim to be anti-exclusion. You are not against the use of exclusion you just think it should be available to use but it's use should be limited
@DanH_9 @OYFallTSM Exactly so you can be pro-deterrent but anti-use
@DanH_9 @OYFallTSM The deterrent is a massive bluff as using nuclear weapons against a country with their own nuclear weapons runs the risk of your country being destroyed with nuclear weapons.
@DanH_9 @OYFallTSM Nope and can't think of a time when a a nuclear war could be justified

@PastoralGuy @DanH_9 @OYFallTSM ..it would be clearer to say ‘exclusions should only be used for xyz’. Your position is then crystal clear and no one is confused. Unless of course the plan all along is to be ambiguous and create some opposition to your stance.

@PastoralGuy @DanH_9 @OYFallTSM My point is you cannot claim to be against the use of something if you say it can in fact happen in certain circumstances. 

I large number of people will have the same opinion which is why saying Anti-exclusion creates such backlash as it implies against all exclusions...
@PastoralGuy @DanH_9 @OYFallTSM Probably because of the use of prefixes which have very clear meanings anti (against) and pro (for).
@DanH_9 @OYFallTSM I disagree if you are anti something then you shouldn’t be able to justify it
@DanH_9 @OYFallTSM So your initial statement of “I’ve never met anyone pro-exclusion” isn’t quite correct as you yourself are pro-exclusion in certain circumstances

@DanH_9 @OYFallTSM You have already said you are “for” the use of violence in certain circumstances and I’ve already explained that ‘pro’ literally means ‘for’ (from Latin) so you are pro violence. All be it in certain circumstances
@DanH_9 @OYFallTSM I’m well aware of that. My issue is you are changing the definition of the prefixes ‘anti’ and ‘pro’ to suit your own narrative.
@DanH_9 @OYFallTSM So that makes you pro violence as ‘pro’ literally means ‘for’. You’re just pro violence in certain circumstances
@DanH_9 @OYFallTSM So you’d be for the use of violence as a means to protect ones self?
@OYFallTSM @DanH_9 Great piece of Comedy thanks for sharing. Not sure why you’ve shared though

@OYFallTSM @DanH_9 Anti originates in Greek and means ‘against’. How can you say you are against something but also say it’s ok if you’ve tried everything else? 

Pro on the other hand originates in Latin and means ‘for’. You can easily say you are for something, but in certain circumstances

@DanH_9 You can be pro-exclusion and not want to see it used. Being pro something is simply about recognising it should be an option not it just used all the time. Being anti something means you are against its use 100%

@jerrydeasley @JamesHandscombe @joon_of @cs_kube …2) the sanction is not proportionate for  meeting a legitimate aim (sending a child who is dysregulated to a calm quiet classroom that is supervised my a member of staff so that they can complete their work is not disproportionate)

@jerrydeasley @JamesHandscombe @joon_of @cs_kube You’re right but only if 
1) they are treated unfavourably due to their disability (if all reasonable steps have been taken to make adjustments for the disability then it would be hard to argue they have been treated unfavourably)..

@grahamchatterl2 @LesterJMilton Actually that wasn’t what I said. I was referring to the fact that the GCSE science curriculum has a significant to amount of surface level knowledge which they do not require a deep understanding of. The understanding of large amounts of science is well beyond GCSE level

@grahamchatterl2 @PastoralGuy @ConnorThomp5on @Behaviour_Guy Never ignored what you have said, I just ask for further clarification or give you my thoughts in it. I went out and bought @Markfinnis book on your suggestion but you often refuse to give further insight when asked to apply what you are suggesting in a scenario I’ve experienced
@grahamchatterl2 @PastoralGuy @ConnorThomp5on @Behaviour_Guy Clearly you don’t even fully understand your own definition of teaching.
@grahamchatterl2 @ConnorThomp5on @Behaviour_Guy @tombennett71 Not necessarily about atoms, compounds & molecules or even bonds
@grahamchatterl2 @PastoralGuy @ConnorThomp5on @Behaviour_Guy Still been, by your own words, taught something
@grahamchatterl2 @ConnorThomp5on @Behaviour_Guy @tombennett71 Not necessarily - KS3 particle model is all brand new ideas so no prior knowledge but can still do independent practice
@grahamchatterl2 @ConnorThomp5on @Behaviour_Guy @tombennett71 So only stuff you remember forever you’ve been taught?
@grahamchatterl2 @PastoralGuy @ConnorThomp5on @Behaviour_Guy So they’ve been taught what they are expected to do
@grahamchatterl2 @ConnorThomp5on @Behaviour_Guy @tombennett71 Except you’re the only one saying the definition has changed.
@grahamchatterl2 @ConnorThomp5on @Behaviour_Guy @tombennett71 They can’t do the independent tasks if I haven’t taught them what to do to start with
@grahamchatterl2 @ConnorThomp5on @Behaviour_Guy @tombennett71 Forgetting is natural don’t beat yourself up. If you’re not using it regularly we forget doesn’t mean you weren’t taught it.
@grahamchatterl2 @ConnorThomp5on @Behaviour_Guy @tombennett71 Well that’s the definition so a good place to start when discussing the meaning of a word. Do you not use words as per their definition?

@grahamchatterl2 @ConnorThomp5on @Behaviour_Guy @tombennett71 If my initial telling is good enough then all I need to do is be on hand to offer support when pupils are doing independent practice. Usually they just ask for confirmation they are doing it right. I then give them the answers to their practice work. 

Have I not taught anyone?

@grahamchatterl2 @ConnorThomp5on @Behaviour_Guy @tombennett71 Still know something I didn’t before. I have new knowledge.

Half of the GCSE science curriculum doesn’t explain what’s actually happening - it’s very surface level facts. Are we not teaching Science?
@grahamchatterl2 @ConnorThomp5on @Behaviour_Guy @tombennett71 Yet they aren’t teaching (remember definition of the word is to impart new knowledge)?
@grahamchatterl2 @ConnorThomp5on @Behaviour_Guy @tombennett71 If teaching starts by telling then being told is being taught.
@grahamchatterl2 @ConnorThomp5on @Behaviour_Guy @tombennett71 Still taught me something because they have imparted new knowledge.
@grahamchatterl2 @ConnorThomp5on @Behaviour_Guy @tombennett71 So no, because they just stand at the front of the hall delivering new content?

@grahamchatterl2 @ConnorThomp5on @Behaviour_Guy @tombennett71 I was once told that the sky is blue because of the way the light from the sun spreads out as it enters the atmosphere and blue spreads more than other colours so we see mainly blue. I didn’t fully understand it but that person taught me something I didn’t know before
@grahamchatterl2 @ConnorThomp5on @Behaviour_Guy @tombennett71 So they don’t teach anything?

@grahamchatterl2 @ConnorThomp5on @Behaviour_Guy @tombennett71 …The point we are both making is that you can teach someone a new idea the first time they are told about it. It doesn’t need them to make mistakes and then require further input in order for them to have been taught. You have imparted new knowledge so have taught them something
